text: Lambda layer for Betfairlightweight. Before trying to build my own, which i suspect will be difficult on a Mac without learning some docker, I wondered whether anybody here already has one working?

elements.text: Lambda layer for Betfairlightweight. Before trying to build my own, which i suspect will be difficult on a Mac without learning some docker, I wondered whether anybody here already has one working?

text: also interested in this :slightly_smiling_face: currently using venv's and it gets painful updating them all

elements.text: also interested in this
currently using venv's and it gets painful updating them all

text: I have used a layer for BetfairLightweight. I didn't use docker, I created it on an EC2 instance. Using this to install locally before creating the zip file for upload: pip3 install betfairlightweight -t ./lambda --upgrade

elements.text: I have used a layer for BetfairLightweight. I didn't use docker, I created it on an EC2 instance. Using this to install locally before creating the zip file for upload: pip3 install betfairlightweight -t ./lambda --upgrade

text: Thanks <@URMM9463X>. That worked, though I'm still wrestling with a couple of issues. Throwing them out here in case other people have better ideas than I come up with.

elements.text: Thanks
. That worked, though I'm still wrestling with a couple of issues. Throwing them out here in case other people have better ideas than I come up with.

text: First is the paths available for python layers on Lambda. Seems I need to root the package at python/lib/python3.x/site-packages/, so the layer gets bound to the version of python I'm using when I create the Lambda function and I'd need to recreate a new layer if I want to upgrade my version of python, which is a bit of a pain.

elements.text: First is the paths available for python layers on Lambda. Seems I need to root the package at python/lib/python3.x/site-packages/, so the layer gets bound to the version of python I'm using when I create the Lambda function and I'd need to recreate a new layer if I want to upgrade my version of python, which is a bit of a pain.

text: Second issue is how to handle the certs and key. Ideally I'd pass them in as strings from the environment variables. But BFL  appears to allow me only to specify a folder or individual files. So I'm thinking maybe my Lambda function needs to be uploaded as a zip file containing the code and a certs folder, but that's extra overhead for each update and I'm not wild about deploying lots of copies of my certs. Alternatively I could try to make the certs folder a layer too.

elements.text: Second issue is how to handle the certs and key. Ideally I'd pass them in as strings from the environment variables. But BFL  appears to allow me only to specify a folder or individual files. So I'm thinking maybe my Lambda function needs to be uploaded as a zip file containing the code and a certs folder, but that's extra overhead for each update and I'm not wild about deploying lots of copies of my certs. Alternatively I could try to make the certs folder a layer too.

text: How about uploading your certs to an S3 bucket and downloading them in your Lambda function?

elements.text: How about uploading your certs to an S3 bucket and downloading them in your Lambda function?

text: Thanks <@UNQGKT0CR>. There's certainly some things to like about that in terms of having a single source of truth, but i'm less keen on having to add some code to each lambda that's a bit tangential to its actual objective. In the end I've put them in a custom layer which was easily accessible at "/opt/certs/", so it was less of an issue than I thought it was going to be.

elements.text: Thanks

. There's certainly some things to like about that in terms of having a single source of truth, but i'm less keen on having to add some code to each lambda that's a bit tangential to its actual objective. In the end I've put them in a custom layer which was easily accessible at "/opt/certs/", so it was less of an issue than I thought it was going to be.

text: Hi Peter, I don't think the Python version / library location is really an issue. Once the layer is there you can just import bflw as you normally would. The trickiest thing for me was the certs part. I created a folder in the Lambda for the certs and used this line of code to reference it iirc: certs = r'task/certs'

elements.text: Hi Peter, I don't think the Python version / library location is really an issue. Once the layer is there you can just import bflw as you normally would. The trickiest thing for me was the certs part. I created a folder in the Lambda for the certs and used this line of code to reference it iirc: certs = r'task/certs'

text: Many thanks <@URMM9463X> for the earlier pointer. I have a fully working version now much more quickly than I expected. So big hat tip to you. I have a number of start of day data collection scripts and strategies that run close to an event's start that I suspect will be more efficient run as lambdas than on a server that's mostly idle for the rest of the time. My concern over the python version, was about ongoing maintenance rather than importing within the lambda, which as you say is trivial, but upon reflection, I would expect to create new layers for upgrades to BFL way more frequently than I upgrade the underlying version of Python, so not really an issue.

elements.text: Many thanks

for the earlier pointer. I have a fully working version now much more quickly than I expected. So big hat tip to you. I have a number of start of day data collection scripts and strategies that run close to an event's start that I suspect will be more efficient run as lambdas than on a server that's mostly idle for the rest of the time. My concern over the python version, was about ongoing maintenance rather than importing within the lambda, which as you say is trivial, but upon reflection, I would expect to create new layers for upgrades to BFL way more frequently than I upgrade the underlying version of Python, so not really an issue.

text: You're welcome <@U9JHLMZB4>. Sounds like your project is similar to something I did, whereby a step function schedules a lambda to run at x minutes before market_start_time. Must be the cheapest way to run BFLW on AWS!

elements.text: You're welcome
. Sounds like your project is similar to something I did, whereby a step function schedules a lambda to run at x minutes before market_start_time. Must be the cheapest way to run BFLW on AWS!

text: For me it's not just the cheapness. It's also the ability to encapsulate a whole task into a small, easily deployed script, and know that there's no risk of contention and that all the infrastructure is taken care of.

elements.text: For me it's not just the cheapness. It's also the ability to encapsulate a whole task into a small, easily deployed script, and know that there's no risk of contention and that all the infrastructure is taken care of.
